questions.text: The following image represents which personality disorder historically?
questions.solution:
• According to Greek myth, Narcissus, a beautiful youth, fell in love with his reflection in the water of a pool and drowned in his attempt to embrace his beloved image.
  • Freud used the term narcissism to describe situations in which an individual's libido was invested in the ego itself rather than in other persons.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 4 Theories of Personality and Psychopathology, Page number 156.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is diagnosed with bipolar disorder, manic type, when she was hospitalized after becoming psychotic, hypersexual, severely agitated and unable to sleep. She is started on a medication in the acute phase of her illness. Which of the following medications, recommended for acute use in manic patients, is recommended to be continued on into maintenance therapy?
questions.solution:
• Lithium, carbamazepine and valproic acid are the agents most often used in the long-term maintenance treatment of bipolar disorder.
  • Antipsychotics and benzodiazepines, while very helpful in the acute treatment of bipolar mania, should be discontinued as soon as the patient is in a stable state and not used in long-term maintenance unless absolutely necessary, given the risk of movement disorders and dependence, respectively.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh Edition, Chapter 29th, Psychopharmacological treatment, Page no 985.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman has been feeling blue for the past 2 weeks. She has little energy and has trouble concentrating. She states that 6 weeks ago she had been feeling very good, with lots of energy and no need for sleep. She says that this pattern has been occurring for at least the past 3 years, though the episodes have never been so severe that she couldn't work. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Cyclothymic disorder is characterized by recurrent periods of mild depression alternating with periods of hypomania.
  • This pattern must be present for at least 2 years(1 year for children and adolescents) before the diagnosis can be made.
  • During these 2 years, the symptom-free intervals should not be longer than 2 months.
  • Cyclothymic disorder usually starts during adolescence or early adulthood and tends to have a chronic course.
  • The marked shifts in mood of cyclothymic disorder can be confused with the affective instability of borderline personality disorder or may suggest a substance abuse problem.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh Edition, Chapter 8th, Mood disorders, Page no: 384.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man is brought into the emergency department after he is picked up by police for wandering around his neighborhood naked. On examination, the patient states that he is 'receiving amazing messages from the cosmosphere' and that he believes that he is destined to do something 'catastrophically wonderful' for the world. He is alternately euphoric and then irritable with the examiner. He states that he wants to go home in the new car he just charged on his American Express card. He denies medical illnesses. The urine drug screen is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this man?
questions.solution:
• The man is presenting with labile mood, inappropriate behavior, grandiose thoughts and excessive spending, all hallmarks of bipolar disorder.
  • Because he is clearly manic at the moment, a cyclothymic disorder, with its smaller highs than full blown mania, is unlikely.
  • Narcissistic personality disorder does not present with frank psychosis.
  • Schizophrenia would be unlikely to present with the labile mood and excessive spending.
  • Schizoaffective disorder would likely present with a background of psychosis with new affective symptoms superimposed.
  • Because we must assume there is no prior history beyond what we have been told in the scenario, bipolar disorder is the best fit.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh edition, Chapter 8th, Mood disorders, Page no: 371.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man has undergone heroin detoxification on the ward. He does not want an opioid maintenance therapy. He has requested medication that could help him to maintain abstinence. What is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
• The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence(NICE) recommends the use of naltrexone(CORRECT OPTION D)for those who prefer an abstinence programme.
  • Patients need to be fully informed of the potential adverse effects and benefits of treatment and should be highly motivated to remain on treatment.
  • Naltrexone treatment has been found by NICE to be a cost-effective treatment strategy in aiding abstinence from opioid misuse.

Reference: Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh edition, Chapter 29th, Page no: 1006.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy diagnosed with attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder(ADHD) is attending your clinic for review. He has been taking methylphenidate for six months with good improvement in his symptoms. His mother reports the emergence of motor tics in the past two weeks and would like a change in her son's medication. Which of the following alternative drug treatments is the most suitable alternative?
questions.solution:
• Atomoxetine is the most suitable alternative.
  • It may be used as a first-line alternative to stimulants such as methylphenidate and dexamphetamine.
  • It may be suitable for children who develop tics while taking stimulants.
  • There is some evidence to support the efficacy of carbamazepine and no evidence to support the use of second-generation antipsychotics(Option B)
  • Risperidone may have a role in those with moderate learning disability.(Option D)

Reference: Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh edition, Chapter 29th, Page no: 1038.

questions.text: Match the following to their respective category of thought disorders:
questions.solution:
• Disorders of stream of thought: Flight of ideas, Prolixity, Circumstantiality
  • Disorders of possession of thought: Obsessions and Compulsions, Thought alienation
  • Disorders of content of thought: Delusions
  • Thought alienation: Thought broadcasting, Thought withdrawal, Thought insertion
  • Other formal thought disorders: Derailment, Loosening of Association

Reference: Fish's Clinical Psychopathology, third edition, Chapter 4 Disorders of Thought and Speech

questions.text: Match the following delusional themes with their syndromic names:
questions.solution:
• Delusion of love: Declarambault syndrome
  • Delusion of infidelity: Othello syndrome
  • Delusion of nihilism: Cotard syndrome
  • Sympathetic pregnancy: Couvade syndrome
  • Delusional misidentification: Capgras syndrome, Fregoli syndrome

Reference: Fish's Clinical Psychopathology, third edition, Chapter 4 Disorders of Thought and Speech

questions.text: A patient presented with sensations of small animals or insects crawling under his right lower limb. Such symptom can be indicative of all the following conditions, except:
questions.solution:
• Sensations of small insects or animals crawling under body signify tactile hallucinations and is also known as formication
  • It is seen commonly in several conditions like:
    1. Cocaine intoxication, where such tactile hallucinations and persecutory delusions are together termed as cocaine bugs
    2. Delusional parasitosis, where person has a delusional belief of insects or animals invading his body and accordingly tactile hallucinations may be present as an extension of this delusion
    3. Delirium
    4. Schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders
    5. Organic brain pathology like cerebrovascular stroke, Parkinson's disease, Dementia
  • Generalized anxiety disorder falls under neurotic spectrum
  • It is not characterized by psychotic symptoms like hallucinations

Reference: Fish's Clinical Psychopathology, third edition, Chapter 3 Disorders of Perception, Page no: 33

choices.text: This condition has not been included in DSM-V
This condition has been specified under Category: Obsessive Compulsive and Related Disorders in DSM-V
This condition has been specified under Category: Delusional Disorder in DSM-V
None of the above statements for this condition are true

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman was referred to Psychiatry Out-patient clinic with complaints of extreme distress due to a false belief that others were visibly offended by her foul body odour, which she described as having a "musty" smell and at times smelling like "stale fish" or stool, emanating from the axillary, genital, or chest areas. She attempted to camouflage the perceived odour by repetitive behaviors like showering twice a day, tucking tissues under her clothing to absorb sweat and moisture and applying antiperspirant approximately 40 times per underarm. Which of the following is true about her condition?
questions.solution:
• The above case is of Olfactory Reference Syndrome
  • Olfactory reference syndrome is characterized by a false belief by the patient that he or she has a foul body odour that is not perceived by others
  • They seem to base their belief on the behavior of other people who, they say, wrinkle their noses or make reference to the smell
  • The preoccupation leads to repetitive behaviors such as washing the body or changing clothes, hence it is included in the "other specified" designation for obsessive compulsive and related disorder of DSM-5
  • The patient may have good, fair, poor, or absent insight into the behavior
  • The syndrome is predominant in males and single status
  • The mean age of onset is 25 years of age

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh edition, Chapter 10, Obsessive Compulsive and Related Disorders, Page 426

questions.text: The following list (A-E) describes the general appearance of various patients presented in a psychiatric out-patient clinic. Match the following to their most likely diagnosis (1-5) based on their general appearance:
questions.solution:
• Bright and colourful clothes with flashing jewellery inappropriate to the context or situation is suggestive of Mania or even Histrionic Personality disorder
  • Dishevelled appearance with shabby and torn clothes, poor self-care and gross self-neglect like unshaved hairs, unkempt look with blank staring at walls and psychomotor retardation is suggestive of Chronic Schizophrenia or psychosis or Severe depression
  • Dull expressions, sad face, furrowing on forehead, Veraguth folds, downward gaze, hunched shoulders, psychomotor retardation is suggestive of depression
  • An anxious person appears as "always on the go", sitting on the edge of a chair, fidgeting his hands, biting nails, having exaggerated startle response and may have physiological signs like sweating, panting, sighing, trembling, etc.
  • Persons with trichotillomania appear to be touching their hairs repetitively, pulling their hairs and even attempting to put pulled hairs in their mouth

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, eleventh edition, taken from various chapters concerning the specific Diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a formal thought disorder?
questions.solution:
• A formal thought disorder is considered to be a schizophrenic language disorder
    • It characterised by disordered speech, and results from disorganised thoughts.
    • It is often a symptom of schizophrenia, mania, severe depression with psychosis and other psychotic disorders.
    • Tangentiality is a formal thought disorder in which there is tangential association of ideas leading to disruption in the smooth continuity of speech.
  • Thought insertion, thought broadcasting, thought withdrawal and thought block are Schneider's first rank symptoms. (Option C & D)
  • Delusion of persecution is a fixed belief in which patients believe that they are being followed, persecuted and spied on, and that the perceived persecutor will cause them harm. (Option A)

Reference: PGNIP2, Cijo Alex, 2nd Edition, Chapter 3, page no. 27

questions.text: An 8-month-old girl enjoyed picking up toys and bringing them to her mouth. She was often seen sucking them. What phase of Freud's psychosexual development is she going through?
questions.solution:
According to Freud there are five stages of psychosexual development. The approximate age range of the stages is characterised by:

  • Oral phase: 1 year of fixation on mouth and lips - relation to sucking, biting and mouthing.
  • Anal phase: 1-3 years of fixation on anal cavity - relation to toilet training.
  • Phallic phase: 3-5/6 years of fixation and sensitivity to genitals. The Oedipus complex occurs only in this stage.
  • Latency phase: 5/6 years of puberty - sexual preoccupations of earlier years repressed.
  • Genital phase: puberty/maturity - new demands and sexual desires.

Reference: Synopsis of Psychiatry, eleventh edition, chapter 4, page no: 157

questions.text: In a X linked recessive disorder presented with intellectual disability and self-injurious behaviour by biting mouth and fingers, what would be the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is a rare disorder caused by a deficiency of an enzyme involved in purine metabolism.
  • The disorder is X-linked; patients have intellectual disability, microcephaly, seizures, choreoathetosis and spasticity.
  • The syndrome is also associated with severe compulsive self-mutilation by biting the mouth and fingers.
  • Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is another example of a genetically determined syndrome with a specific, predictable behavioural pattern.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 31.3, Intellectual disability, Page number 1124.

questions.text: After death of a regional celebrity by suicide, it was observed that the suicide rate in that region rose, with individuals committing self-injurious acts by emulating the same method of suicide as that celebrity. This form of suicidal behavior is known as:
questions.solution:
• A copycat suicide is defined as an emulation of another suicide that the person attempting suicide knows about either from local knowledge or due to accounts or depictions of original suicide on television and in other media. (CORRECT OPTION B)
  • The publicized suicide serves as a trigger, in the absence of protective factors, for the next suicide by a susceptible or suggestible person.
  • Suicides occasionally spread through a school system, through a community, or in terms of a celebrity suicide wave, nationally.

choices.text: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder combined type

questions.text: Parents of a 10-year-old boy note that their son does well with his family until he is not allowed to do something he wants to do. When this occurs, he will get irritable, impulsively aggressive, and agitated for several hours. Once he calms, or gets his way, he is happy and pleasant again. At school he has no trouble focusing but if he does not want to do something, he becomes argumentative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The pattern described best fits oppositional defiant disorder, because the patient can be seen to calm down and be pleasant after he gets his way
  • A child with bipolar disorder might be seen to have these kinds of outbursts, but the mood dysregulation continues, even after the child 'gets his way' (OPTION B)
  • Children in the midst of a bipolar disorder never 'calm down and become pleasant'. Depressed children would also have a persistent mood shift (OPTION D)
  • The symptoms of inattention and distractibility are not present, so the patient does not have Attention Deficit Hyperactive Disorder (ADHD) (OPTION C)

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh edition, Chapter 31.12d Oppositional Defiant Disorder, page no. 1245

questions.text: A 23-year-old college student comes to the physician because her roommates are worried about her eating. She tells the physician that she regularly eats large amounts of food(more than 10,000 calories on occasion) and then has to 'punish herself' and 'get rid of it'. She explains that she does this by sticking her finger down her throat, which causes her to vomit. She tried to hide this activity from her roommates, but on more than one occasion they have heard her retching in the bathroom. The patient is 5'5" tall and weighs 132 lb. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This college student has the classic symptoms of bulimia, in which she eats huge amounts of food (binging) and then feels the need to "get rid of it" (purging)
  • Her body mass index (BMI) is within a normal range and therefore anorexia is ruled out.
  • Avoidant/restrictive food intake disorder is more commonly found in children, and at any rate, this woman's food intake is anything but restrictive (OPTION B).
  • Likewise, while she does binge, she also purges, making binge-eating disorder less of a good fit than bulimia (OPTION D).
  • Pica is the eating of non-nutritional objects that are not meant to be consumed (e.g., lead paint chips).
  • There is no history of this given in the vignette.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh edition, Chapter 15.2, Bulimia Nervosa, Page no. 517.

questions.text: Match the following personality disorders with their characteristic patterns:
questions.solution:
• Paranoid personality disorder→ long-standing suspiciousness and mistrust of persons in general
  • Schizoid personality disorder→ lifelong pattern of social withdrawal. Persons with schizoid personality disorder are often seen as eccentric, isolated, or lonely
  • Antisocial personality disorder→ inability to conform to the social norms that ordinarily govern many aspects of a person's behaviour
  • Narcissistic personality disorder→ a heightened sense of self-importance, lack of empathy, and grandiose feelings of uniqueness
  • Avoidant personality disorder→ extreme sensitivity to rejection and may lead socially withdrawn lives. Although shy, they are not asocial and show a great desire for companionship, but they need unusually strong guarantees of uncritical acceptance

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh edition, Chapter 22, page no. 742

questions.text: A young boy has suffered road traffic accident on NH-16, 2 months back, presents with complaints of horrible dreams about the accident. He is afraid of going to that highway again. He has visualization of same accident again and again. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Flashback and nightmare, avoidance are the features of PTSD

Reference: Kaplan and Saddocks Synopsis of Psychiaitry, 11th Edition, Chapter 11, Page No.: 440

questions.text: Pinto is a 50-year-old male who reports that his biggest problem is worrying. He worries all the time and about 'everything under the sun', e.g. he reports equal worry about his wife who is undergoing treatment for breast cancer as well as whether he returned his book to the library. He is unable to control his worrying. Along with this, he also had difficulty falling asleep, difficulty focusing at work and significant back and muscle tension. Recently, such worries have aggravated after his wife was detected with breast cancer. Which is the most appropriate diagnosis for him?
questions.solution:
• People who seem to be anxious about almost everything are likely to be classified as having generalized anxiety disorder.
  • Generalized anxiety disorder is defined as excessive anxiety and worry about several events or activities for most days during at least a 6-month period.
  • The worry is difficult to control and is associated with somatic symptoms, such as muscle tension, irritability, difficulty sleeping, difficulty in attention and concentration and restlessness.
  • Depression with anxious distress is ruled out as his mood is not described as depressive primarily and criteria for Major Depressive episode is not met(Option A).
  • While Illness anxiety disorder is characterised primarily by theme of constant worrying about own health and contracting an illness(Option B).
  • Panic disorder comprises of frequent spontaneous panic attacks, which is not the case here as his anxiety symptoms do not amount to panic(Option C).

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh edition, Chapter 9.6, Generalised Anxiety disorder, Page 409.

choices.text: 6 to 12 hours after his last drink
12 to 24 hours after his last drink
24 to 48 hours after his last drink
48 to 96 hours after his last drink

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with a 12-beer per day drinking history for the last year presents to the emergency department with headache, stomach upset and tremulousness after deciding to quit drinking cold turkey earlier that day. On examination, he is afebrile with normal vital signs. He is alert and oriented to person, place, time and situation. The man appears diaphoretic and anxious. If this patient were to progress to delirium tremens, how many hours would this be expected take?
questions.solution:
• This patient is experiencing early symptoms of alcohol withdrawal which typically begin within the first 6 to 12 hours following the last drink.
  • Alcoholic hallucinosis, characterized by visual, tactile and auditory hallucinations without disturbances in attention or awareness, occurs within 12 to 24 hours and lasts up to 48 hours.
  • Delirium tremens rarely occurs before the 48-hour mark and may not appear until up to 96 hours from the last drink.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh edition, Chapter 20, Alcohol-Related disorders, Page no. 630.

questions.text: Match the following cannabis preparations to the parts of cannabis sativa plant they are derived from:
questions.solution:
• Bhang is derived from the flowering tops
  • Charas/Hashish from dried leaves
  • Ganja from resinous exudate from stem of Cannabis Sativa plant

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Chapter 20.4, Cannabis-related disorders, Page number 644.

questions.text: A 25 year old female is presented to OPD with complaints of agitation, muttering to herself and sleep disturbances. She claims that her husband has stolen the baby from her womb. She has delivered a healthy child three weeks back, however has not taking care of the baby. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Nihilistic delusion is associated postpartum and duration is around 3 weeks. Diagnosis is Postpartum psychosis.

Reference: Kaplan and Saddocks Synopsis of Psychiaitry, 11th Edition, Chapter 8, Page No.: 357

questions.text: A patient believes that one real person is replaced by another, as shown in photo. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Capgrass Syndrome: Patient believes that a familiar person has been replaced by an imposter. It is also known as "DELUSION OF DOUBLE".

Fregoli syndrome: Patient believes that a familiar person can change his appearances and disguise as a stranger.

Reference: Fish's Clinical Psychopathology, Signs and symptoms in Psychiatry, 3rd edition; STEPs Clinical Notes-2019, Index, Page No: 121

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room by her husband after she begins screaming that her children are calling to her and becomes hysterical. The husband states that 2 weeks previously, the couple's two children were killed in a car accident and since that time the has been agitated, disorganized and incoherent. He states that she will not eat because she believes he has been poisoning her food and she has not slept for the past 2 days. The patient believes that the nurses in the emergency room are going to cause her harm as well. The patient is sedated and later sent home. One week later, all her symptoms remit spontaneously. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Characterized by the sudden appearance of delusions, hallucinations and disorganized speech or behaviour, usually following a severe stressor.
  • The episode lasts at least 1 day and less than 1 month and is followed by full spontaneous remission.
  • For the woman in the question, the psychotic episode was clearly precipitated by the death of her children.
  • Schizophreniform disorder is differentiated from brief psychotic disorder by temporal factors(in schizophreniform disorder, symptoms are required to last more than 1 month) and lack of association with a stressor(OPTION B).

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh Edition, Chapter 7.5, Brief psychotic disorder, Other Psychotic Disorders and Catatonia, Page no. 339.
